See the best Geminid meteor shower 2024 photos from around the world - Space.com
summary:
See the best Geminid meteor shower 2024 photos from around the world

Publication Date: December 14, 2024 Source: Space.com

The Geminid meteor shower dazzled skywatchers this week with stunning displays captured across the globe, even under the challenge of a full moon.

  • The Geminids are known for their bright meteors and high hourly rates.
  • Photographer Osama Fathi captured impressive images of the shower from Egypt's Black Desert.
  • In Hawaii, the Subaru Telescope recorded over 150 meteors in one hour despite bright moonlight.
  • Amateur astronomers shared their best captures from various locations including Canada and Japan, showcasing the meteors along with notable celestial objects.
  • Various photographers documented unique phenomena during the shower, including multiple meteors appearing simultaneously.
"Despite the meteor shower coinciding with a full moon this year, I managed to capture this image before its peak, successfully recording several meteors despite the presence of some light clouds that added an artistic touch to the light." - Osama Fathi

The Geminid meteor shower continues to be a highlight for astronomers and astronomy enthusiasts alike, proving that even challenging conditions can yield breathtaking celestial displays.
newTitle: Spectacular 2024 Geminid Meteor Shower Photos Captured Worldwide

title: 5 Majestic Pictures Of Space Captured By NASA - Times Now
summary:
5 Majestic Pictures Of Space Captured By NASA

Publication Date: Dec 15, 2024 | Source: Times Now Digital

This article showcases five stunning images of space captured by NASA’s advanced telescopes, highlighting various celestial phenomena.

  • NGC 3603: A brilliant cluster of young stars resembling a fireworks display.
  • Eta Carinae: A massive star on the verge of a supernova explosion.
  • Helix Nebula: A breathtaking view combining detailed and expansive perspectives.
  • Starburst Galaxy NGC 1569: An extraordinary starburst galaxy producing stars at an accelerated rate.
  • Carina Nebula: A view revealing hidden stellar nurseries and vibrant regions of star formation.
“Together, they create a seamless and breathtaking view of the Helix Nebula.”

This collection reveals the beauty and complexity of the universe, demonstrating NASA's capabilities in astrophotography.
newTitle: 5 Majestic Pictures Of Space Captured By NASA

NASA’s Juno probe reveals factors driving excessive volcanism on Io - News9 LIVE
summary:
NASA’s Juno probe reveals factors driving excessive volcanism on Io

Publication Date: New Delhi,
Source: Science News

Io is a moon of Jupiter with an estimated 400 volcanoes that continuously erupt, covering its surface in volcanic material. Observations from NASA's Juno probe suggest that each volcano is powered by its own magma chamber, rather than a shared subsurface magma ocean. This discovery helps to clarify the origins of Io's volcanic activity, a question that has puzzled scientists since the Voyager I mission in 1979.

  • Io is the most volcanic body in the Solar System, featuring around 400 volcanoes.
  • The research indicates that volcanoes on Io are powered by separate magma chambers.
  • This finding challenges previous assumptions of a global ocean of magma beneath Io's surface.
  • The data was collected during close flybys of Io in 2023 and 2024 by the Juno spacecraft.
“Since Morabito’s discovery, planetary scientists have wondered how the volcanoes were fed from the lava underneath the surface.” - Scott Bolton

This research provides vital insights into the geological activities of Io and will likely influence future explorations and studies of volcanic bodies in our Solar System.
newTitle: NASA’s Juno Probe Uncovers Secrets of Volcanism on Jupiter's Moon Io

title: Hubble captures grand design spiral galaxy bursting with stellar nurseries - News9 LIVE
summary:
Hubble captures grand design spiral galaxy bursting with stellar nurseries

Publication Date: New Delhi

Source: Science News

The Hubble Space Telescope has revisited the spiral galaxy NGC 5643, located 40 million light years from Earth, revealing bright blue stars and stellar nurseries.

  • NGC 5643 is classified as a ‘grand design’ spiral galaxy.
  • The galaxy features bright blue stars which are young and energetic, surrounded by stellar nurseries.
  • Hubble's new observations include additional frequencies not captured in previous images.
  • A supermassive black hole at the galaxy's center is actively feeding on gas and dust.
  • The galaxy also hosts a smaller black hole that emits bright X-ray radiation.
The emissions from the infalling material cause the gas and dust to glow brightly in X-ray and ultraviolet frequencies.

The remarkable images from Hubble continue to enhance our understanding of the formation and evolution of galaxies.
newTitle: Hubble Captures Stunning Images of Spiral Galaxy NGC 5643

title: Scientists reveal how dust storms can engulf Mars - News9 LIVE
summary:
Scientists Reveal How Dust Storms Can Engulf Mars

Publication Date: New Delhi

Scientists have investigated the conditions that form catastrophic dust storms on Mars, which can span the entire planet. A team has discovered these storms can be triggered by warm and sunny days, providing groundwork for predicting extreme weather events on Mars.

  • Dust storms on Mars can block sunlight and deposit material on solar panels of probes.
  • About 68% of major dust storms were preceded by sharp increases in surface temperatures.
  • Conditions that trigger Martian storms are similar to those causing storms on Earth.
  • The researchers aim to monitor live data from Mars to predict dust storms reliably.
“The dust storms can start off as smaller storms near the polar ice caps, and then grow at a furious rate.”

The research enhances our understanding of Martian weather patterns, which can improve safety for future missions to Mars.
newTitle: Scientists Reveal How Dust Storms Can Engulf Mars

title: NASA tests lifting body atmospheric probe - News9 LIVE
summary:
NASA Tests Lifting Body Atmospheric Probe

Date: New Delhi, August 1, 2024

Source: Science News

The latest NASA tests unveil innovative atmospheric probes that utilize a unique lifting body design for potential exploration beyond Earth.

  • NASA is experimenting with lifting body aircraft, which use their fuselage for lift rather than traditional wings.
  • The atmospheric probe was launched from a quadcopter in California, demonstrating stable flight characteristics.
  • An improved release mechanism allowed for successful deployments after initial design challenges.
  • The goal is to design probes capable of flying in thick atmospheres, such as those found on Venus or Titan.
“It was completely stable in flight. We will be looking at releasing it from a higher altitude to keep it flying longer and demonstrate more maneuvers.”

This innovative approach may transform future space missions by facilitating extended data collection from other worlds' atmospheres.
newTitle: NASA Tests Lifting Body Atmospheric Probe

title: Webb and Chandra Telescopes In Space Team Up For Amazing Imagery - MSN
NASA reveals Mars exploration programme 2024-2044 - News9 LIVE
summary:
NASA has revealed plans for exploring the Red Planet in the near future.

Publication Date: New Delhi

Source: Science News

Mars is being prepared for human arrival over the next decade, with missions aimed at building communication infrastructure and exploring astrobiological potential.

  • Nasa's upcoming missions will enhance communications and weather monitoring on Mars.
  • Collaboration with private industries to deploy a satellite relay network for GPS-like services on Mars.
  • Digging deeper into international partnerships and human exploration opportunities.
  • Utilization of 'rough' landing techniques to deliver payloads to Mars.
“NASA is also focusing on time-sensitive missions that have to be carried out before the first humans venture to Mars.”

This ambitious plan outlines a future where human exploration of Mars becomes a reality, harnessing both technological advancements and international cooperation.

7 Stunning Pictures Of Interacting Galaxies Captured By NASA Hubble Space Telescope - Times Now
summary:
7 Stunning Pictures Of Interacting Galaxies Captured By NASA Hubble Space Telescope

Date: Dec 15, 2024 | Source: Times Now

This article showcases seven breathtaking images of interacting galaxies captured by the NASA Hubble Space Telescope, highlighting the beauty and complexity of these cosmic events.

  • Arp 148 showcases the aftermath of a collision between two galaxies, resulting in unique formations.
  • Two Spiral Galaxies pass each other gracefully in the constellation Canis Major.
  • Portrait of Stephan’s Quintet reveals five galaxies, with one being a foreground galaxy.
  • The image of NGC 3717 depicts a spiral galaxy located about 60 million light-years away.
  • Arp 248 highlights two galaxies in a gravitational interaction.
  • NGC 3921 illustrates the significant influence of galaxy mergers on evolution.
  • A Pair of Interacting Galaxies shows a duo in the Coma galaxy cluster, showcasing their intricate cosmic dance.
“Today, we understand that galaxy mergers significantly influence galaxy evolution.”

These images not only captivate but also provide insight into the dynamic universe we inhabit.
newTitle: 7 Stunning Pictures Of Interacting Galaxies Captured By NASA Hubble Space Telescope

title: Astronomers Unveil the Mysterious 350,000-Mile Tail of Exoplanet WASP-69 b - SciTechDaily
NASA’s Perseverance Rover Reaches the Top Rim of the Jezero Crater - Universe Today
summary:
NASA's Perseverance Rover Reaches the Top Rim of the Jezero Crater

Publication Date: December 12, 2024 Source: Universe Today

NASA's Perseverance rover has successfully reached the top of Jezero Crater’s rim, marking a significant milestone in its exploration of Mars. This achievement enables the rover to begin its “Northern Rim” campaign, aimed at examining geological features indicative of past life.

  • The Perseverance rover climbed 500 meters to reach Lookout Hill.
  • It will now embark on a journey covering 6.4 km to investigate aur four sites of interest.
  • This campaign focuses on understanding ancient geological formations and searching for biosignatures.

“The Northern Rim campaign brings us completely new scientific riches as Perseverance roves into fundamentally new geology.” – Ken Farley, project scientist

This achievement opens new possibilities for understanding Mars’s history and its potential for past life.
newTitle: NASA's Perseverance Rover Reaches the Top Rim of the Jezero Crater

title: NISAR planned to launch in March 2025 after antenna repairs - SpaceNews
summary:
NISAR Planned to Launch in March 2025 After Antenna Repairs

Publication Date: December 11, 2023

Source: SpaceNews

NISAR, a joint mission between NASA and ISRO, is now set to launch in late March 2025 following delays for repairs to its radar antenna.

  • The launch was initially planned for Spring 2024 but was postponed due to antenna issues.
  • The spacecraft's reflector was too warm after testing and needed repairs, which involved a return to California.
  • NISAR will utilize L- and S-band radars for Earth mapping, with operations starting three months post-launch.
  • The mission is a significant collaboration, with NASA investing over $1 billion.
“Some of the temperatures were higher than we expected them to be,” said Gerald Bawden, program scientist for NISAR.

The launch is now targeted for late March 2025, contingent on the completion of repairs and refurbishments at the launch site.
newTitle: NISAR Planned to Launch in March 2025 After Antenna Repairs

title: Two Distinct Populations of Dark Comets Delineated by Orbits and Sizes - Astrobiology News
summary:
Two Distinct Populations of Dark Comets Delineated by Orbits and Sizes

Publication Date: 10 Dec 2024 | Source: Astrobiology

This article discusses the discovery of two distinct populations of dark comets, which were found to display different sizes and orbital characteristics. Researchers report on newly detected non-gravitational accelerations in additional dark comets, providing insight into their possible origins and implications for Earth's development.

  • Dark comets are small bodies that may deliver essential materials for the development of life.
  • Recent findings identify additional dormant near-Earth dark comets exhibiting non-gravitational accelerations.
  • These dark comets lack visible comae, traditionally a sign of comet activity.
  • Two populations of dark comets have been delineated: larger “outer” comets on eccentric orbits and smaller “inner” comets on near-circular orbits.
  • The discoveries are significant for understanding the life cycle of volatile-rich populations in the Solar System.
"This set of dark comets reveals the delineation between two distinct populations..." - Darryl Z. Seligman et al.

In conclusion, the research sheds light on the complex interactions between dark comets and their potential role in delivering vital elements to early Earth, potentially revising our understanding of cometary activities.
newTitle: Two Distinct Populations of Dark Comets Delineated by Orbits and Sizes

title: Marius, the man who named Jupiter’s Galilean moons - The Hindu
summary:
The Legacy of Simon Marius: The Man Who Named Jupiter’s Moons

Published on: December 15, 2024 | Source: Unknown

Simon Marius, a contemporary of Galileo, faced accusations of plagiarism in his scientific discoveries, notably those regarding Jupiter's moons and Andromeda Galaxy.

  • Plagiarism has been a significant concern in academia, impacting reputations.
  • Simon Marius was born in 1573 and was known for his scientific contributions, including naming Jupiter's moons.
  • Marius constructed a telescope and made significant astronomical discoveries, including the moons of Jupiter.
  • The debate regarding Marius's discoveries versus Galileo's has lasted centuries.
  • His book, Mundus Iovialis, published in 1614, included observations of the Andromeda Galaxy.
“... four tiny stars, sometimes behind, sometimes in front of Jupiter, aligned in a straight line with the planet.”

Although the significance of Marius's contributions has often been overshadowed by allegations of plagiarism, he played a crucial role in naming the Galilean moons, which are now essential to the study of astronomy.
newTitle: The Legacy of Simon Marius: The Man Who Named Jupiter’s Moons

title: Probing The Gas That Builds Planets: Results From The JWST MINDS Program - Astrobiology News
summary:
Probing The Gas That Builds Planets: Results From The JWST MINDS Program

Date: December 14, 2024 Source: Astrobiology

Infrared observations with JWST open up a new window into the chemical composition of the gas in the inner disk (<few au) where planets are built.

  • Results from the MIRI GTO program MINDS are presented for several disks around T Tauri and lower-mass stars.
  • A large diversity in spectra is found, with some disks rich in H2O lines while others show prominent CO2.
  • Disks around very low-mass stars are dominated by C2H2 and hydrocarbon features suggesting volatile C/O>1.
  • The data point to a rich chemistry in the inner regions linked to the physical structure of these disks.
E.F. van Dishoeck, the MINDS team

These findings present significant implications for our understanding of planet formation and the conditions of early solar systems.
newTitle: Probing The Gas That Builds Planets: Results From The JWST MINDS Program

title: Webb Telescope unveils a Milky Way-like galaxy from the early universe - Madhyamam
Our 6 Favorite Space Stories of 2024 - ExtremeTech
8,000-Kilometer Deep Oceans on Uranus and Neptune? A Scientist’s Revelation - Indian Defence Review
summary:
8,000-Kilometer Deep Oceans on Uranus and Neptune? A Scientist’s Revelation

Published on: December 14, 2024

Source: Indian Defence Review

A groundbreaking study published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences suggests that Uranus and Neptune may conceal vast oceans beneath their atmospheres, potentially extending up to 5,000 miles deep.

  • A thick hydrogen-helium atmosphere
  • A deep ocean of water
  • A layer of highly compressed hydrocarbons

The unique magnetic fields observed by NASA’s Voyager 2 probe may also be explained by this composition.

Implications for the search for extraterrestrial life

This discovery opens up exciting possibilities for searching for life beyond Earth and indicates potential habitable environments on moons like Miranda.

Advancements in planetary modeling

Recent advancements in machine learning allowed researchers to create a model simulating atom behavior under extreme conditions, supporting the proposed layered structure.

Future exploration and confirmation

A dedicated mission to Uranus or Neptune is needed for direct confirmation of these findings, which could launch by 2034.
newTitle: 8,000-Kilometer Deep Oceans on Uranus and Neptune? A Scientist’s Revelation

title: Earth's subterranean hydrogen reserves could usher in a fossil fuel-free future - Madhyamam
Building the virtual cell with artificial intelligence - Tech Explorist
summary:
Building the Virtual Cell with Artificial Intelligence

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: Tech Explorist

Advances in artificial intelligence are converging with extensive biological data to create the first virtual human cell, paving the way for significant breakthroughs in understanding human biology and disease.

  • Stanford University, Genentech, and the Chan-Zuckerberg Initiative are leading efforts to harness AI for biological modeling.
  • The virtual cell could simulate how human cells function and lead to new therapies.
  • AI will help researchers simulate experiments on computers instead of using live cells.
  • Three main objectives are required for the AI virtual cell: universal representations, accurate cellular function predictions, and enhanced computer-based experimentation.
  • The project demands a collaborative global effort across multiple scientific disciplines.
“This is a mammoth project, comparable to the genome project, requiring collaboration across disciplines, industries, and nations.” – Emma Lundberg

The pursuit of the AI virtual cell could revolutionize biology but requires substantial collaboration and accessibility within the scientific community.
newTitle: Building the Virtual Cell with AI: A New Frontier in Biology

title: NASA's Ingenuity Helicopter May Become Weather Station for 20 Years on Mars - Gadgets 360
summary:
NASA's Ingenuity Helicopter May Become Weather Station for 20 Years on Mars

Publication Date: January 19, 2024, Source: Gadgets 360

The Ingenuity Mars Helicopter has been repurposed into a weather station after a crash during its 72nd flight, allowing it to continue gathering data from the Martian surface.

  • Ingenuity suffered rotor damage on January 18, 2024, making it non-flyable.
  • Despite the crash, its systems remain operational for data collection on Mars.
  • The helicopter will record telemetry and images every sol for up to 20 years.
  • Future communications depend on the Perseverance rover, 3 km away, with potential contact loss within a month.
  • JPL is considering a new Mars helicopter design with enhanced capabilities.
“She still has one final gift which is that she's now going to continue on as a weather station.” – Teddy Tzanetos

The Ingenuity helicopter, originally intended for flight tests, transitions to a vital scientific role, offering sustained observation capabilities on Mars.
newTitle: NASA's Ingenuity Helicopter May Become Weather Station for 20 Years on Mars

title: Ligand-engineered copper nanoclusters may aid in fight against CO2 emissions - Tech Explorist
summary:
Ligand-Engineered Copper Nanoclusters May Help Reduce CO2 Emissions

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: Tech Explorist

Researchers from Tohoku University, Tokyo University of Science, and the University of Adelaide have unveiled a groundbreaking method for improving the selectivity and sustainability of electrochemical CO2 reduction processes through the engineering of copper nanoclusters.

  • Copper (Cu) is gaining recognition for its versatility in sustainable chemistry.
  • Engineered copper nanoclusters show promise in converting CO2 into valuable products.
  • The research aimed to control product selectivity at an industrial scale, addressing previous challenges.
  • Two structurally identical Cu₁₄ nanoclusters were produced using different thiolate ligands, showcasing diverse product selectivity.
  • This advancement could lead to more efficient and reliable electrochemical CO2 reduction techniques.
“These findings are pivotal for advancing the design of Cu NCs that combine stability with high selectivity, paving the way for more efficient and reliable electrochemical CO2 reduction technologies,” - Professor Yuichi Negishi, Tohoku University.

This research highlights the importance of copper in sustainable chemistry and the necessity of international collaboration in addressing global carbon emission challenges.
newTitle: Ligand-Engineered Copper Nanoclusters May Help Reduce CO2 Emissions
